comment._content: Hi orangecats, the small wording says 'Hotpoint / THRIFT UNIT / WITH / OIL COOLING / SEALED IN STEEL'
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 13469158@N05
comment._content: Looks ca. 1938 as there are no Monitor Top fridges on display, but there are Flat Tops, which was the replacement.  By this time the Monitor Top name was now seen as outdated, so the compressor mechanism which had been used in the Monitor Tops was renamed the "Thrift Unit" and survived for a few more years in the Flat Tops.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/13469158@N05] Love your work, cablehack - aka Knower of Fridges! Thanks!
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 13469158@N05
comment._content:
I've identified them from my GE manual. PB6-40 cabinet, which means 1940 models.
A touch later than I thought.
General Electric fridges of the era were imported from the U.S.A, by Australian General Electric as there were no facilities here to make the sealed units.  Hotpoint was one of the A.G.E brands.

comment.realname: State Library of New South Wales
comment.author: 29454428@N08
comment._content: I don't think we had the type of American fridge here with the coiling on the top. We did have kerosene fridges but the standard early electric fridges always looked like the ones here.
comment.authorname: State Library of New South Wales collection

comment.author: 13469158@N05
comment._content: The Monitor Top fridges (with compressor & condenser on top) were imported into Australia. They were fitted locally with 240-110V transformers, made by AGE, under the cabinet. I have two 1934 models. One reason for their rarity here is that they were only sold in the larger cities and towns that had 50 cycle mains (that rules out Perth with 40 cycles, and all the rural areas with DC mains). I first saw one in 1979 at a friend's grandmother's house; she was still using it. Searching on Trove will reveal some of the newspaper advertisements for them. e.g. trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/35932312?searchTerm=moni...|||l-australian=y|||l-category=Advertising|||l-decade=193|||l-year=1935
